title: Gosselin2025 - Ecoli_bioproduction_insensitive
content: MODEL2506160001 Gosselin2025 - Ecoli_bioproduction_insensitive Kinetic model for bioproduction via an acetyl-CoA insensitive pathway, as detailed in DOI 10.1101/2025.06.17.659982. html CC0 https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/legalcode Individual SBML (L2V4) https://identifiers.org/combine.specifications:sbml.level-2.version-4 ordinary differential equation model http://identifiers.org/mamo/MAMO_0000046 NON_CURATED 10.1101/2025.06.17.659982v1 DOI bioRxiv preprint Acetate as a metabolic booster for glucose-based bioproduction in Escherichia coli Toulouse Biotechnology Institute http://identifiers.org/doi/10.1101/2025.06.17.659982v1 Escherichia coli, a key workhorse in industrial biotechnology, is commonly grown on glucose, which supports rapid growth but leads to acetate overflow. Acetate has long been regarded as a toxic by-product, known to divert carbon away from production pathways, inhibit cellular growth, and reduce productivity. Recent studies suggest that acetate may also have beneficial effects in glucose-grown E. coli, but its potential in bioprocesses remains unexplored. In this study, we systematically investigated acetate’s impact on bioproduction using a kinetic model of glucose and acetate metabolism in E. coli. The model predicts that acetate can enhance bioproduction in glucose-grown E. coli through three mechanisms: (i) by minimizing acetate overflow, thereby reducing carbon loss, (ii) by increasing acetyl-CoA levels, thereby boosting the biosynthetic flux of acetyl-CoA-derived compounds, and (iii) by promoting biomass accumulation, thus improving overall productivity. We experimentally validated the predictions of the model for mevalonate and 3-hydroxypropionate production, where acetate supplementation increased productivity by 117% and 34%, respectively. Our findings provide a valuable framework for optimizing E. coli-based bioprocesses and highlight acetate’s underutilized potential in biotechnology. By leveraging acetate from waste streams as a metabolic booster, this approach could contribute to more sustainable and environmentally friendly bioprocesses. Millard, Denis Jallet, Erwana Harscoet, Uttenweiler-Joseph, Stéphanie Heux, Millard, Millard AnnotationCurator pierre.millard@insa-toulouse.fr 0000-0002-8136-9963 o1 INRAE Gosselin2025_Ecoli_bioproduction_insensitive True application/xml doi Ordinary differential equation model mamo biomodels.db working/aaj/MODEL2506160001/2/Gosselin2025_Ecoli_bioproduction_insensitive.xml MAMO_0000046
author: Millard
